gurmukhi: qj kY Apny Brqw hmrI miq kwnH jU aUpir qoih rmI ]Aiq hI qn kwm krw aupjI qum kO ipKey nih jwq CmI ]471]
transliteration: Taj Kai Apne Dhartaa Hamrimat(i) Kaahn Joo Oopar(i) Toh(i) Ramee|| At(i) Hitan Kaam Karaa Oupjitoum Kau Pikhae Nah(i) Jaat Chhamee||471||
translation: “We have come to Krishna after leaving our husbands because the influence of the power of lust is formidably increasing in our body and seeing you, we could not suppress those powers.”471.

gurmukhi: Bgvwn lKI Apny mn mY ieh gÍwrn mo ipK mYn BrI ]qb hI qij SMk sBY mn kI iqn kY sMg mwnuK kyl krI ]
transliteration: Bhagvaan Lakhiapne Man Mai Eh Gvaaran Mo Pikh Main Bharee|| Tah Hitaj(i) Shank Sabhai Man Kitin Kai San Maanoukh Kel Daree||
translation: Krishna thought in his mind that these gopis had been intoxicated with lust on seeing him; then he, without any hesitation, copulated with them like ordinary men;

gurmukhi: hir jI kir Kyl ikDO ien so jnu kwm jrI ieh kI n jrI ]kib sXwm khY ipKvo qum kOqk kwn hrXo ik hrI su hrI ]472]
transliteration: Har(i) Jikar(i) Khel Kidhau In So Jan(u) Kaam Jarieh Kina Daree|| Kabi Syaam Kahai Pikhvo Toum Kaoutak Kaan Daryo Ki Harisu Daree||472||
translation: He absorbed himself with the gopis who were blazing with lust; the poet Shyam says that in this amorous play, it is beyond comprehension whether Krishan has created the gopis or gopis have cheated Krishna.472.

gurmukhi: jo jug qIsr mUrq rwm DrI ijh Aaur krXo Aiq sIlw ]SqRn ko su sMGwrk hY pRiqpwrk swDn ko hr hIlw ]
transliteration: Jo Joug Teesar Moondat Raam Dharijih Aur Daryo At(i) Seelaa|| Shatran Ko Su Sanhaarak Hai Prateepaarak Saadhan Ko Har Heelaa||
translation: He, who incarnating in Treta age as Ram, performed many other works of gentleness, the same is the destroyer of the enemies and the protector of saints in all conditions;

gurmukhi: dÍwpr mO soaU kwn BXo mrIAw Air ko DrIAw pt pIlw ]so hir BUim ibKY biRj kI his gopn swQ krY rs lIlw ]473]
transliteration: Dvaapar Mau Sooo Kaan Bhayo Dareeaa Ar(i) Ko Ddareeaa Pat Peelaa|| So Har(i) Bhoom(i) Bikhai Brij Kihas(i) Gopan Saath Darai Ras Leelaa||473||
translation: The same Ram, in Dvapara age, is the wearer of yellow garments as Krishna and is the killer of enemies; he is absorbed now in amorous play smilingly with the gopis of Braja.473.

gurmukhi: mwl isrI Aru rwmklI suB swrMg Bwvnw swQ bswvY ]jYqsrI Aru su`D mlHwr iblwvl kI Dun kUk sunwvY ]
transliteration: Maal Siriar(u) Raamkalisoubh Saaran Bhaavanaa Saath Basaavai|| Jaitsariar(u) Suddh Malhaar Bilaaval Kidhoun Kook Sounaavai||
translation: He is causing everyone to listen through the tunes of his flute the musical modes of Malshri, Ramkali, Sarang, Jaitshri, Shuddh Malhar and Bilawal;

gurmukhi: lY murlI Apny kr kwnH ikDo Aiq Bwvn swQ bjwvY ]paux clY n khY jmunw iQr moih rhY Dun jo sun pwvY ]474]
transliteration: Lai Murliapne Kar Kaahn Kidho At(i) Bhaavan Saath Bajaavai|| Paoun Chalai Na Kahai Jamounnda Thir Moh(i) Rahai Dhoun Jo Soun Paavai||474||
translation: Taking his flute in his hand, Krishna is playing on it and listening to its sound the wind and Yamuna have become motionless, whosoever listens to his tune, gets allured.474.

gurmukhi: kwnH bjwvq hY sur so Pun gopn ky mn mY joaU BwvY ]rwmklI Aru su`D mlHwr iblwvl ko Aiq hI Tt pwvY ]
transliteration: Kaahn Bajaavat Hai Sur So Phoun Gopan Ke Man Mai Jooo Bhaavai|| Raamkaliar(u) Suddh Malhaar Bilaaval Ko At(i) Hitthat|| Paavai||
translation: Krishna is playing on the flute whatever pleases the gopis; Ramkali, shuddh Malhar and Bilawal are being played in an extremely charming way; hearing the sound of the flute,

gurmukhi: rIJ rhY su surI AsurI miRg Cwif miRgI bn kI cl AwvY ]so murlI mih sXwm pRbIn mno kr rwgn rUp idKwvY ]475]
transliteration: Reejh Rahai Su Suriasurimrig Chhaad(i) Mrigi Ban Kichal Aavai|| So Mrilimaih Syaam Prabeen Mano Kar Raagad Roop Dikhaavai||475||
translation: The wives of gods and demons are all getting pleased and the does of the forest are coming running abandoning their deers. Krishna is so much expert in playing on the flute that he is manifesting virtually the musical modes themselves.475.

gurmukhi: sun kY murlI Dun kwnHr kI mn mY sB gÍwrn rIJ rhI hY ]jo giH logn bwq khI iqnhUM Pun aUpir sIs shI hY ]
transliteration: Soun Kai Mrlidhoun Kaahnar Kiman Mai Sabh Gvaaran Reejh Rahihai|| Jo Grih Logad Baat Kahitinhoon Phoun Oopar(i) Sees Sahihai||
translation: Listening to the sound of the flute all the gopis are getting pleased and they are enduring all sorts of talks of the people gently;

gurmukhi: swmuih Dwie clI hir ky aupmw iqhkI kib sXwm khI hY ]mwnhu pyK smsn ky muK Dwie clI imil jUQ AhI hY ]476]
transliteration: Saamuh(i) Dhaae Chalihar(i) Ke Oupmaa Tihkikabi Syaam Kahihai|| Maanoh Pekh Samsan Ke Moukh Dhaae Chalimil(i) Jeeth Ahihai||476||
translation: They are running towards Krishna like the gathering of serpents springing of red worms.476.
